repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This is a part of #26369. Related to #27067.

------

Explicitly use normal grey foreground in syntax groups where it was previously implicitly assumed. This is to make it work better with @-groups and their fallback mechanism. More info in commit message.

------

Update default treesitter groups. Basic idea is to define less in default color scheme, yet just enough to be useful. That is:
- All first level groups (`@character`, `@string`, etc.).
- All `@xxx.builtin` groups as a most common subgroup.
- Some special cases (links/URLs, `@diff.xxx`, etc.).

Defining less groups reduces maintenance burden. It also reduces user's surprise when not defining certain group doesn't mean that it will be highlighted based on its fallback (I experienced this myself even though I was aware of how default color scheme defined groups).

@clason, after spending time thinking about this, I'd ask if this ok with you for default color scheme to not define `@markup.environment` at all? Not sure if this significant enough to be part of *default* color scheme.

Note: another extreme would be to document that all highlight groups present in `:h treesitter-highlight-groups` should not be expected to comply with fallback mechanism. To me this feels as somewhat not clean approach.

comment_data.body:
I do think there's an expectation that the different types of keywords are highlighted accordingly; otherwise it's a notable regression over the legacy highlighting (with the same theme).

(In general I agree with the strategy to rely where possible on the implicit fallback; that's what it's there for.)

comment_data.body:
Unfortunately, there are semantic issues here after renaming.
Previously several groups which are now considered (based on naming) under the "keyword"/"statement" umbrella were not there. Those are:
- `@include` / `Include` (no highlighting).
- `@storageclass` / `StorageClass` (no highlighting).
- `@debug` / `Debug` (linked to `Special`).
- `@preproc` / `Preproc` (no highlighting).
- `@define` / `Define` (no highlighting).

With this PR, all their `@keyword.xxx` alternatives will fall back to `@keyword` which is bold. So this is not really a regression, but indeed a change with more groups being recognized (in default color scheme) as keywords.

comment_data.body:
If them being bold is intended, that is fine with me. As I said, you're now taking ownership of the treesitter groups, and colorschemes are on their own to define them.

So this _is_ a regression or change (things that have no highlighting or `Special` highlighting with legacy syntax have bold highlighting with treesitter). The question is whether this is intended/acceptable.

comment_data.body: Oh, yes very much so intended. At the moment (after considering alternatives) I do think relying as much as possible on semantic/fallback structure of new groups is better here. So instead of trying to link `@keyword.import` to `Include` and force legacy syntax sematics to be the reference, new `@keyword` hierarchy is the reference. And as keywords are documented to be bold by default, so be it.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
The following is a list of standard captures used in queries for Nvim,
```
Sorry. But that at least is marginally correct, unlike what the spelling police made of my suggestion.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -422,8 +422,9 @@ instance, to highlight comments differently per language: >vim
     hi @comment.lua guifg=DarkBlue
     hi link @comment.documentation.java String
 <
-The following captures are linked by default to standard |group-name|s (use
-|:Inspect| on a group to see the current link):
+The following is a list of standard captures used in Nvim queries,

@@ -422,8 +422,9 @@ instance, to highlight comments differently per language: >vim
     hi @comment.lua guifg=DarkBlue
     hi link @comment.documentation.java String
 <
-The following captures are linked by default to standard |group-name|s (use
-|:Inspect| on a group to see the current link):
+The following is a list of standard captures used in Nvim queries,

comment_regular_data.body:
While I agree that `@markup.environment` is really niche, I think it would be good for the sake of expectation to have every group in `:h tree-sitter-highlight-groups` highlighted, either explicitly or via a fallback.

I should also point out that there's a tension here between defining useful fallbacks for _every_ colorscheme (which is what I implemented) and having a fine-tuned default colorscheme (what you implement here). I'm not arguing that either is preferable; just making clear that these goal conflict. It's important for messaging: "The default links are for the default theme; it's expected that custom themes define **all** documented groups themselves and not rely on default links."

> While I agree that `@markup.environment` is really niche, I think it would be good for the sake of expectation to have every group in `:h tree-sitter-highlight-groups` highlighted, either explicitly or via a fallback.

In general I agree, that is why every first level @-group is explicitly linked. All other documented highlight groups I'd expect to be judged on case by case basis. This PR shows how I currently would approach all of those cases.

> I should also point out that there's a tension here between defining useful fallbacks for _every_ colorscheme (which is what I implemented) and having a fine-tuned default colorscheme (what you implement here). I'm not arguing that either is preferable; just making clear that these goal conflict. It's important for messaging: "The default links are for the default theme; it's expected that custom themes define **all** documented groups themselves and not rely on default links."

Yes, that's what was my note at the bottom of the first comment. To resolve the mentioned tension, I am more leaning towards defining less by default and allowing users to fine tune. This is partially explained that defining more groups (especially keywords) might require using explicit definitions instead of links to play nicely with default color scheme. This doesn't play nicely with "define default links for all color schemes".

I don't think I like the approach that users should not expect certain subset of groups to not use fallback mechanism. But I guess the note in documentation should be added nevertheless, because even with this PR there is such subset of groups, just smaller.

The only situation when this is not the case is if default links are created only for first level groups. This would still be doable, but to my taste much less useful.

> I don't think I like the approach that users should not expect certain subset of groups to not use fallback mechanism. But I guess the note in documentation should be added nevertheless, because even with this PR there is such subset of groups, just smaller.

I strongly prefer "all or nothing" here:
1. default colorscheme users should expect everything to work out of the box
2. (users of) other colorschemes should expect to have to define all documented groups themselves.

(Of course, they're still welcome to tweak 1 if they're _almost_ happy with it; my point is just that the "90% happy path" that we consider necessary to support and document covers only 1. and 2., nothing in between.)

Here's my suggestion for the help text (right before the list in `:h treesitter-highlight-groups`, replacing the sentence starting "The following...":

"
The following is a list of standard captures used in Neovim queries, highlighted according to the current colorscheme (use `:Inspect` on one to see the exact definition):
"

> "
> The following is a list of standard captures used in Neovim queries, highlighted according to the current colorscheme (use `:Inspect` on one to see the exact definition):
> "

Used this in the new update. Also removed `@markup.environment` as it has fallback to `@markup`.

Did not touch 'news.txt' as it is an ongoing work already mentioned there.
Looks good, will merge when CI is done. Thanks for keeping up the good work!

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: Tweak treesitter groups in default color scheme
